intro: Adenophora marsupiiflora var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy cupflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of China. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, hairy flowers that bloom in summer. The plant has a hairy stem and leaves, which contribute to its common name. It typically grows in rocky or dry habitats, showing adaptability to harsh environments. The flowers are often visited by pollinators such as bees and butterflies, making it an important species in its ecosystem.
